channel.title: Website of Fergus Fettes
channel.description: Recent content on Website of Fergus Fettes

item.title: Reflections on 2020
item.description:
It is increasingly obvious that the toll of this year will be long and slow in the coming. You feel it in every little interaction, people are different. It will take people a long time, it will take society a long time, to recover. And if we are heading into a major economic recession, some things won’t get the chance to recover for a decade or more.

Apart from the obvious, it was a wonderful year for me. I started it in Leipzig as always, drinking beers on Eisenbahn with the Irish lads, talking to Paul Frazee about transformative tech (I met him at the CCC and asked if he was doing anything for New Years Eve).

January and February were full of gigs and events (my third or fourth time attending the HGB Rundgang in Leipzig, my first visit to the Akademie in Vienna), and I started hanging out with my now flatmate Sophie. We discovered some very interesting bars and got picked up by all kinds of characters, Herwig being a fine example. I bought my finest jacket, a traditional Austrian leather tracht that must be a century old. I joined an art collective.

Just before the lockdown, I moved in with Sophie so we could save money for an apartment. Little did we know what would happen. I spent 10 weeks sleeping on her sofa in a 27m^2 apartment. We were both working and studying full time from there. It was intense. We watched some Gaspar Noe films and I learned 3D modeling in Blender. We studied some economics (specifically, I followed an economics 101 lecture series from MIT on youtube while playing Factorio for a weekend). I learned Javascript and the basics of web publishing.

Then the lockdown ended, and we moved into a beautiful Vienese apartment, 114m^2 (and vastly higher, the cubic meterage must be immense). We had some flatwarming parties. We got some flatmates.

I went to Scotland for a month to do some farming, and Sophie and Jurgen came with. We built a beautiful flight of stairs and started planning a residency.

Then it was September. September, October and November were largely taken up (besides work) with the collapse of my relationship with my then fiancee. We also had some nice dinner parties in our apartment, particularly the turkish dinner series cheffed by my brother, and semi-regular brunches. During this time I also had a wonderful weekend in east Germany with my collective, and I achieved my longest-ever water fast (10 days). There were many things in this month that I should write about in more detail at some point.

I worked as a python developer/devops engineer in a tech startup for the entire year. I am apparently not too bad at having a career, I got two raises and a promotion in the year, despite the dreaded ‘rona. I got a lot of responsibility, and learned a great deal, not only about programming/systems engineering, but also about working with others, managing others, managing my time etc.

The emotional turmoil of the end of the year led me to take some time to consider my plans in some detail. I spent a lot of time talking with my friends, and realised more and more that I would like to go back and do a PhD. Then AlhpaFold cracked the protein folding problem. I feel more and more certain that this field is going to be incredibly exciting in the next decades.

I was in a quiz show!

Finally, I came home to Scotland for my first Christmas at home in a very long time. (We tried to remember when it would have been, probably 2013.) I bought and played RimWorld.

All in all it has been a long and varied year with many ups and downs. Better than most people had I imagine.

I worry very much about how we are all doing now. And how we will be doing by springtime. They have invented a new Tier of lockdown over here. They are desperately trying to keep us alive until the vaccine is ready.

I had what probably amounts to a massive breakdown this year, and I am not particularly prone to these things. This may have been on the cards, but it was no doubt hastened and worstened by the virus. I have no doubt that many people are suffering the same or worse, and the density and frequency of meltdowns is a very important factor in the functioning of a society.

Perhaps appropriately, this year I learned about Nick Land, and accelerationism. I learned that there are some who would like to push the self-destructive tendencies of capitalism to an extreme and watch it collapse. I feel like it is more possible than ever, in this tense and bitter air. Pent-up energies building into something.

item.title: Todo, 2021
item.description: (aka. New Years Resolutions)

item.title: Spotify Stars from the Current Times (2020-2021)
Music-I-Like
item.description:
Intro

I like listening to music. I try to listen widely, but also (somewhat) deeply, getting into niche genres and exploring the landscapes I find there. I had a quite tepid entry into music appreciation, growing up listening to Leonard Cohen, Bob Dylan, the Red Hot Chili Peppers, and whatever happened to be popular at the time among my peers (I’m of the Limp Bizkit generation so you can image what that means).

While I was at university, in my early 20s, my musical horizons were broadened, and continued to broaden throughout my twenties. I started listening more and more widely not only to ‘popular’, contemporary music, but also taking a fairly slow, broad pass through the history of classical music. Below I have summarized some of my listening habits of the past ten years.

Spotify

I have been using spotify for almost ten years now. Back in the day I used to like songs and make playlists, but for the past 7 years or so I have listened almost exclusively to albums. I curate my downloaded albums quite closely, deleting things that become too familiar (though there are many guilty pleasures that I download and delete again and again) and always making sure I have a good collection of unfamiliar music downloaded.

To deal with the fact that I always deleted music I know, I realised I needed a hardcopy of my listening habits. So I got a little book in which I would periodically write down the best music I had been listening to recently. Sometimes I would forget to update it for quite a while, but generally every month or two I would write down some highlights. In the front of the book I wrote down ‘classical’ music, in the back ‘popular’ albums. I recently digitized these lists12 on my journey home (a disasterous train journey from London during a Tier 4 lockdown). Looking at them, I feel like they are strangely sparse and sad. I love listening to music and do it almost incessantly. Are these two lists really representative of what feels like such a significant part of my life?

In an effort to delve further, I also exported my old Liked/Starred Songs playlist3. Cringeworthy as some of my old taste is, I feel like this works better as an active snapshot of listening, and I recently started starring songs again. My intention with my starred list is not to create a playlist that I would particularly want to listen to, but to keep a record of songs from albums I like. So every song on my new list should been seen as a pointer to an album (though they are of course normally my favourite or the most catchy song). I will export and update this list regularly4, and probably rotate every year.

Of course Spotify is only a small part of my listening. Here I will list some other sources.

Youtube

Youtube is a fantastic source for curated piano music. This is my main reason to go there. Here are some of the best channels I’m aware of:

  • Ashish Xiangyi Kumar
    • The classic ‘wonderfully curated piano music with blurbs and sheets’. Long may Xiangyi rule the channels.
  • Medtnaculus
    • Another good one.
  • Flavi Chan Samurai Music Investigator
    • Freaky music from all over the world with a strong oriental inclination. Some of my favourite discoveries are either from here or present here (Miharu Koshi, Haruomi Hosono, this track which has to be one of my favourite grooves of all time).

Youtube is also a great for really weird stuff that wouldn’t show up in most musical catalogues, like a 20-minute long piano interpretation of Kavinskys Outrun which I once saw and (to my enduring regret) didn’t immediately download, or fantastic pieces like everywhere at the end of time or this 5-and-a-half hour long piece trying to get you used to a different tuning method. Or shaky-cam home footage of unusual choirs from around the world.

Also, I have a weakness for Anthony ‘Best Teeth in the Game’ Fantano and have gotten several recommendations from him. I can’t claim that this is the most profound source in the world but he does fine work nevertheless.

I also watch Adam Neely sometimes, but not for his reccis. Minor shoutout.

VK (Russian Facebook)

Thanks to their very relaxed copyright policies, VK is a great place to find wonderfully well curated collections on particular niche topics, particularly stuff that you might struggle to find elsewhere.

Personally, I was using it to explore Japanese pop music from the 70s and 80s (City Pop, see here for an example). Yamashitter, properly tagged jpop and vintage jpop are a good place to start.

However their ‘Awesome Tapes From Africa’ section is also great. (I mean you could also just follow that record label of course.)

Other

Soulseek

I haven’t gotten much into it yet but I hear it is the dream for things that can’t be found elsewhere.

Soundcloud

I only use Soundcloud to listen to this one song that was produced by a friend of a friend, and my old partners solo stuff. I should really dive in there for the really cutting edge stuff, I know. But I tend to listen to much more older and more established music than the state-of-the-art. That is neither to my credit nor discredit in my opinion.

Literature

Occasionally I want to here some opinions about the music I like. I generally look up whatever album I’m considering on Pitchfork on these occasions.

Other than that, there are two sources I should mention: Piero Scaruffi, a physicist I think? I have no idea how I discovered that list, but I have gotten some good stuff from there.

And finally, Ted Gioia. I am working through that list just now. Having gotten halfway through 2019, I’m realising that I need to start skipping the jazz and the folk singers that he recommends, but there is so much weird and fascinating stuff from all over on those lists that I think he will continue to be a great source for many years to come.

Conculsions and Acknowledgements

I would like to thank the youtube algorithm and the many many youtube channels that I cannot credit because I have never known them, for their tireless work. I think it is very likely that the sources credited above (which the exception of ‘spotify, generally’) actually make up a small proportion of what I listen to, with much more coming from diverse sources in the youtube or spotify algorithmic radio.

I would like to thank ublock origin for making youtube bearable. (I pay for Spotify, but do not do so with the mistaken believe that that constitutes supporting artists.)

Finally, I would like to acknowledge that in fact, most of my musical journey (at least in contemporary music) has been driven largely by the fact that I have had the very good fortune to live with people who have been various degrees of music journalist/musician/music obsessive, and it was these people who set me on my way and kept me on the straight and narrow; in approximate order of when they started supplying me regularly with reccis:

  1. Kevin Mulligan
  2. Hanna Lemmik
  3. Diarmuid Morgan
  4. Emma Ludwig
  5. Felix Opper
  6. Sophie Nam Koong

And special mentions to Felix Mulligan, my brother Max, and Gesa Maass for contributions.

  1. www.fergusfettes.com/lists/classical-2013-2020.md ↩︎

  2. www.fergusfettes.com/lists/popular-2013-2020.md ↩︎

  3. www.fergusfettes.com/lists/spotify-2011-2013.md ↩︎

  4. www.fergusfettes.com/lists/spotify-2020-2021.md ↩︎

item.title: Christmas
item.description:
Home for Christmas, distributig all the computers and tablets I have been playing with in the last week. I’m keeping the foldable bluetooth keyboard though, soo my keyboard and phone function as a nice pocketable writing setup.

Bought Rimworld. Very fun. It is very relxaing and pleasant to play a Dwarf Fortress clone that is not full of bugs and incredibly complex to play. Maybe their steam version will fix some interface problems, but it realy seems like Rimworld has learnt almost every useful lesson from DF and just made it much cleaner and simpler to work with.

It should be noted that it is still very clear how different they are in terms of depth of simulation. Rimworld is no replacement for DF. But perhaps we will start to see somethinng emerge that is the convergence between playability and depth.

item.title: Music and time
item.description:
Musical tastes chart a neat journey. Their immediacy and impact make it easy to jump back to an earlier time. I can look at a list of music I listened to 8 years ago1 (when I started using Spotify), and I can hear so much of the music immediately upon reading the name, and anything I have forgotten I can recall at the touch of a button.

When I think of how my reading tastes have changed, I have to work harder to really remember the books I read when I was younger, and there are many which I now realise I took in in a strange naive way. Of course I listened strangely when I was younger too, but at least I can very quickly listen again and try to compare how I feel now to how I remember feeling. But maybe this practice does my former self too little credit– some of the music I find cringeworthy now was heard in a context that I don’t have access to any more.

I am going to upload my first Spotify liked list, I have already digitized my lists of classical2 and 3 musics (I had a little book I would occasionally update). Now that I have started making Spotify liked lists again, I will continue my old habit of saving and refreshing them every 500 songs. Lets see how the tastes continue to change.

On Spotify liked lists: I didn’t like songs for many years, because I focusing on listening to albums and thought playlists of songs were kind of trivial. But I’m now remembering how nice it is to have a chronology of your listening, and a list to scroll through when you want to find something good you heard recently.

  1. /Lists/spotify-likes-1/ ↩︎

  2. /Lists/music1/ ↩︎

  3. /Lists/music2/ ↩︎

item.title: x220 Experiments 2
item.description:
So my first set of RAM arrived and I installed it. I’m starting to get the impression that upgrading your computer is absurdly easy. It seems the laptop took longer than normal to start up. So ill do a little set of experiments to test this:

RAM size RAM maker SDD/HDD Laptop Startup Time Suspend off time Suspend on time
4 GB Samsung HDD new 1 1:46 5 9
4 GB Samsung SSD new 1 36 7 8
16GB Crucial HDD new 1 1:46 10 10
16GB Samsung HDD new 1 1:38 10 7
16GB Crucial SSD new 1 36 8 7
16GB Samsung SSD new 1 38 6 7
8GB Samsung SSD old 35 6 3
8GB Samsung HDD old 1:25 10 4
16GB Samsung SSD old 28 7 3
16GB Samsung HDD old 1:28 9 5

Not quite comprehensive but decent coverage of the combination space. It seems the suspend tests have a lot of variance, probably not a good metric, but the startup times show a clear patterns. This result would surprise noone of course but its nice to see it played out in front of you. Takeaway: SSDs forever. Even when it is running you see a huge difference.

item.title: Todos and lists
item.description: I’m going to add a hidden section for todos, recommendations and other lists, find it here.

item.title: Alacritty Ascii
item.description:
Alacritty is one of the many lovely developer tools that are springing up as the first flush in the Rust revolution. Its a fantastic terminal that I’m sure I will have more to say about in due time.

As noted, I discovered something lovely while transferring some files the other day. I was moving my small film collection (currently stretching to 7 titles: <INSERT FILMS>) from one computer to another, and I just wanted to sanity check that the transfer had succeeded. So I sshed into the machine ssh work and ran vlc -I dummy ~/films/Mullholland\ Dr.mkv.

Imagine my surprise to see the criterion logo appear, animated before me. Here is a nice still from another film to illustrate:

You can also look at a copy-paste of the terminal here to prove that it really is ASCII output.

Zooming out, the resolution becomes better and better (text), but it starts to jitter quite badly at a certain size.

I thought the ssh connection might be a bottleneck, so I went to the computer to try it on one machine. I had that slightly haunted feeling that the magic might disappear, and when I entered the terminal I suddenly wondered

How will I get it to work here? If I run vlc -I dummy ~/filmes/Crash.mkv I’ll just get a window.

but as soon as the thought was there I realised I could just start with ssh localhost. And it worked. I was watching the ‘Universal’ logo barge into my terminal.

But things got even better. I noticed that my keystrokes were even getting sent back to vlc, so I could skip forward, pause and even quit the film (sometimes it gets stuck and I have to killall vlc but so it goes).

After a little sleuthing, I notice that

vlc -I dummy ~/films/film.choice

is interactive, but

vlc ~/films/film.choice

is not. What is this dummy terminal doing after all? Well, the vlc wiki has a little info1, and they nicely point out that keystrokes are sent back. I find the terminology a little odd, since ‘dummy video output’ is just normal video output, but I think they are looking at it from a gui-makers perspective. And this seems to be the key– with the dummy interface, vlc streams the movie to a window. Alacritty is presumably pretending to be a screen or a window of some sort, in order to pass its work to the GPU, so VLC merrily dumps the video stream in there.

What I would love to know, and I might take some time to investigate, is how is Alacritty mapping the video stream to ASCII? And why?

I will leave this story here for now. I have two things in mind: one, to investigate further over at the Alacritty github and two, to have some people round for a film, run it through Alacritty-ASCII and run the audio through a digital soundcard or some synths, and make a little performance. I’ll update if either of these things transpire.

In the meantime, if you want to try it yourself, I have uploaded a slightly rushed video of the effect in action (the size limit on asciinema was not made with 4k ASCII movies in mind, so no hard feelings). Asciinema cast attached2.

And here is a final zoomed in still to admire. In the attached text you can see how much of a difference the color makes, presumably a lot of the 8s have the same foreground and background color.

  1. https://wiki.videolan.org/Documentation:Modules/dummy/ ↩︎

  2. https://asciinema.org/a/378193 ↩︎

item.title: x220 Experiments 1
item.description:
I decided to learn a little more about computer hardware by upgrading my latop. I bought a second one for parts/testing.

Quick specs (original):

Purchase date: 2016 (second hand)
Cost: €300
Battery life (playing youtube on firefox, ubuntu 20.04): 76 minutes
Battery type: 9 cell
RAM: 8GB
MEM: 150GB SSD
CPU: Intel Core i5-2520M (2.5-3.2 GHz, 3MB L3 Cache)
CPUS: 4
GPU: Intel HD Graphics 3000

Note on battery life: this laptop has the extended 9-cell battery which was excellent until recently. I’m not sure if there was something specific that damaged it. It went from several hours to the above. Also worth noting is that its self-assessment was wildly innacurate, it said it had less than ten percent left after 10m, but in fact this was about a tenth of the way through. Also I realised after an hour that the screen brightness was low which might make a difference, but since the biggest issue was obviously the battery self-assessment it doesn’t matter too much.

Quick specs (new 1):

Purchase date: 09.12.2020
Cost: €150
Battery life (playing youtube on firefox, ubuntu 20.04): 112 minutes
Battery type: 6 cell
RAM: 4GB
MEM: 300GB HDD
CPU: Intel Core i5-2520M (2.5-3.2 GHz, 3MB L3 Cache)
CPUS: 4
GPU: Intel HD Graphics 3000

The battery on this one is better. Not only does it know what is going on (showed consistent times throughout), it also lasts longer. After swapping the battery packs, it is clear that the first one is faulty, not the laptop. Thank god for a test machine.

From what I read, I can get 16GB of RAM, and I’ll change the SSD and the battery and see if I can get a new one for cheaper than my old one with better specs across the board.

I’m choosing to do this on the x220 since it is the most popular hacktop, so there is loads of info about what works and what doesn’t. And the good news is, there are versions with better chips (though they are more expensive) so even when I have fully upgraded my one, it will still be possible to go further. Hopefully this way I can survive until a new generation of decent machines comes out (with smartphone chips, a la the new macbook).

Final note: the new one is matt black, the other was shiny. And the keyboards have a different touch.

New commands:

lscpu               # cpu overview
cat /proc/cpuinfo               # Good place to go for cpu info
sudo lshw -C display                # For gpu info
sudo lsblk -d -o name,rota                # lsblk is great for when you are meddling with mounts and disks, but this was especially cool-- it finds the 'rotatability' of all devices, so you can check if you have an ssd or an hdd. This also found the dvd reader on my new dockingstation!

item.title: Alacritty and ASCII
item.description:
I made my terminal play a film today. I will investigate further and write up some details. It’s some wizardry with alacritty, I assume it achieves gpu acceleration by pretending to be a screen and running all its content to the GPU. But how this translates into an entire movie being blasted through my terminal I’m still not sure.

I’ll investigate further and do a full write-up.

The key:

ssh localhost 'vlc -I dummy ~/films/Crash'

item.title: First real microblog entry
item.description:
Hello world! I’m continuing my slightly anachronistic (or preposterous) tour of Web publishing. I started with a threejs megaproject, and now I’ve travelled all the way back (via simple paperjs attempts) to a static http website. Marvellous.

I think I’ll stay here for a while, build up some foundations, then head back up the ladder of complexity. Maybe one day I will finish my 3d playground!

This microblog is written on my phone in gitjournal, built with Hugo (I still don’t have a build pipeline set up so I run the following script whenever I want to update the site), then published with GitHub pages. Marvellous!

#!/usr/bin/env bash

(
cd journal
git pull
)

(
cd ffettes
rm -rf public/*
hugo -D
)

(
cd ffettes/public
git add .
git commit -am "$1"
git push
)

git add .
git commit -am "$1"

item.title: About
item.description:
I grew up in a fishing village in the north of Scotland. I learned to be steady on my feet running over seaweed covered rocks. We moved to a farm. I learned to climb trees. Then I grew up and moved to the big city, and climbed on slimy rooftops and up gutters. Then I became civilized, and went to university.

While studying for a Physics MSc. I worked for three years in a molecular biophysics laboratory developing microscopy techniques for studying DNA-protein interactions, including hardware and software engineering and a little bit of wetlab work. After taking a year out to further develop my programming skills I’m now working as a python programmer in a tech startup.

I was civilized by artists in Leipzig, they took me in and told me how to survive in the 21st century. I’m now living in Vienna, continuing to learn these lessons.
